data.title: :memo: Add label property info on enum settings
Opened project folders are not persisted?
data.body:
### Description

One of the most useful features that I constantly use is adding a project folder. This effectively means that, on the same Atom instance, I can work on several projects at once (sometimes completely unrelated projects.)

As of 1.8.0 I can't remove a project folder. Well, it is removed when requested, but on the next Atom startup the folder re-appears. I have tried under safe mode and I observe the same thing.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Add several projects to the running instance using the _Add Project Folder..._ menu item.
2. (optionally) Close Atom and start it up again. All the folders show up in the tree view.
3. Remove one of the above projects by right clicking on top of it, and then _Remove Project Folder_. At this moment the project is indeed removed from the tree view.
4. Close Atom and start it up again.
5. All the folders show up in the tree view, including the removed one.
### Versions

Running under Ubuntu Linux 16.04 `atom --version` yields

```
Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

and `apm --version`

```
apm  1.9.2
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.11+
git 2.7.4
```

Note that **previous Atom versions, i. e., 1.7.x, worked as espected**. I started seeing this behavior after upgrading to 1.8.0. Unfortunately I have only access to Ubuntu, so I can't try to replicate under other OSes.

data.title: [bug] Pressing spacebar inside package install search bar scrolls page.
data.body: In the install page of settings, in the search bar, typing a space causes the page to scroll which makes the search bar go out of view. I'm in 1.8.0

data.title: upgrade electron version to latest stable version
data.body:
### Description

It seems that atom is designed to work a legacy version of Electron (namely version "0.37.8")
While the latest stable version is "1.2.2".
- https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/package.json#L15
- http://electron.atom.io/

Actually Electron 1.x works fine.

**Expected behavior:** use latest stable version.

**Actual behavior:** use of very old legacy version.
### Additional information

Fedora copr and Arch AUR ship atom that uses latest Electron and it's working fine.

Some minor issues that can be easily fixed are reported and can be fixed like this one

https://github.com/atom/autocomplete-plus/pull/726

data.title: [idea] command string insertion
data.body: When we bring up the command menu by pressing cmd-shift-p (OS X in my case), it'd benice to have a shortcut that we can press to insert the selected command's string into the current buffer. This would make it easier to insert the commands into `keymap.cson`. Currently I have to use resolver, and I have to open Element Inspector to copy the command values since the resolver text can't be selected directly, so this idea would make it much easier to write keymaps.

data.title: cmd + click + any_other_key still creates multiple cursors
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

When a user presses CMD + Click + any other button, multiple cursors are created.

The guard here doesn't seem to be strict enough: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/748dbcdced73875e47ad5c337927e8425e0a552d/src/text-editor-component.coffee#L571.

I bring this up because I have a command triggered via `CMD + Alt + Click` and it (undesirably) creates multiple cursors. I can't find a way to programmatically disable the multiple cursor feature under that condition. Ref https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/7595.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. In a text editor, place your cursor anywhere
2. Press CMD + K + Click in a different location within the text editor

**Expected behavior:** multiple cursors should only be created if only `CMD + Click` is executed.

**Actual behavior:** multiple cursors are created
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

data.title: [OSX] Unexpected behavior hitting spacebar in Settings pane
data.body:
### Description

In Atom Settings pane, whenever you press the spacebar (space action) in a textbox the UI scrolls down of one page (approx). The problem is also experienced in safe mode. 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Settings (cmd+,)
2. Select one of the sub-panes (e.g. Keybindings, Packages, etc.)
3. Have the text cursor in one textbox
4. Hit the spacebar

**Expected behavior:** I expect to just have a space in the textbox.

**Actual behavior:** You get a space in the textbox while the UI, if possible, scrolls down of one page (approx).
### Versions

Atom: 1.8.0
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome: 47.0.2526.110
Node: 5.1.1

System version: OS X 10.11.5 (15F34) - OSX El Capitan
Kernel version: Darwin 15.5.0

data.title: Go To Declaration / Show In Tree View not working (Python)
data.body:
### Description

Not sure where exactly to log this as I'm fairly new to Atom. The **Go To Declaration** feature used to work fine using the combination of `alt + cmd + g`. The only related keybindings I can see are as follows, but they don't seem to work either.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1520135/15957236/fe26c67e-2eed-11e6-914e-3636a3d5fa24.png)

Nothing shows up in the developer tools when trying these keyboard combinations.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Highlight /click any function or import that exists in another file in your project.
2. Press `alt + cmd + down`
### Expected behavior

The file where the function/import is located should be opened and the cursor should be placed on the line that contains the function/import.
### Actual behavior

Nothing.
### Versions

Atom: 1.8.0
OS X: 10.11.5

data.title: [idea] Keep settings views in memory for a while instead of re-rendering
data.body:
Every time I switch away from, then come back to the settings tab, it takes a noticeably long time to load.

I'm guessing the view gets destroyed, then when I come back reconstructed based on saved state.

A possible solution is to disconnect the view from the DOM, but not destroy it. When returning to the route (for example) then we can simply re-append the view. If the route has not been returned to within some amount of time, we can destroy the route after a timeout set with setTimeout.

data.title: Uncaught Error: Invalid text decoration iterator position: (133, 122).Buffer row 133 has length ...
data.body:
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]

**Atom Version**: 1.9.0-beta0
**System**: Mac OS X 10.11.5
**Thrown From**: Atom Core

data.title: Feature Request: AND operator for project search to allow search for multiple words irrespective of order
data.body:
### Description

"Search Project" is used to find and replace code in the entire project. Often however, it is used just to find and open a certain file (whose title you might have forgotten). For this application, it would be crucial to be add the AND operator to project search (or add an option to make the search independent of order) so that the only criterion is whether the words occur and how often, so that a search for e.g. "word1 word" would find "word1 word2", "word2 word1" but also "word1 word4 (newlines...) word2"...

data.title: Add .github/ folder
Refresh Project View
data.body:
This is not a bug report but more of question on how to find my way around having just installed Atom for the first time.

I am working on a symfony project which on at the begining generates entity files when you define schema in yml files from the cli. However, I am unable to view the directory and generated files on my project view. I have tried to google, searched here and even tried to find packages that can achieve my requirement for a way to refresh the project tree view with no success. 

Can anyone point me to the right direction?

data.title: State Save : Reopen last file
data.body:
### Description

File's state before it was closed is not maintained when it is re-opened. Cursor is always at the beginning of the page no matter where you were last time.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open any file.
2. Do some work.
3. Close it
4. Reopen it with Ctrl + Shift + T

**Expected behavior:** It should take the cursor to the place where it was last when file was closed. Preferably, word.line selection, if any, should also be maintained.

**Actual behavior:** Keep the cursor at the beginning of the page
### Versions

Atom    : 1.7.4
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

I don't really know how to describe the issue. As you can see in the screenshot below, Atom appears to be highlighting a lot of words, but I'm not sure how or why.
